title: Open data in practice: Visulisation and communication
displayTitle: Open data in practice: Visulisation and communication
body: Communicating impact from data is a key skill of any modern data worker. This course takes participants though the essentials of preparing and visulising data.
instruction: The structure of the day is briefly described below.

_items.title: Cleaning open data
_items.body: There is no such thing as a perfectly clean dataset. So before you can start using data you will need to clean it. This session gives you the skills to quickly clean and prepare a dataset for use.

_items.title: Enriching open data
_items.body:
A single dataset will rarely contain all the information you need to tell as story.

This session gives you the practical skills to quickly enrich a dataset using open and freely available services on the web.

_items.title: Visualising open data
_items.body:
Visualisation data can help quickly reveal insight.

This session takes a practical look at producing advanced interactive Visulisations on the web.

title: Getting started with Data Cleaning
body:
Data cleaning is essential to ensure that when the data is used, the right conclusions are made.

Often errors are not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over many years. In other cases, errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like mistyping or incorrect abbreviations.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will, however, save substantial time in the long-run.

Follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

title: Common errors in data
body: There are a number of common errors in data that you should look out for in any dataset you are working with.

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

Another challenge is that some applications, like Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened, which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: Multiple representations
_items.body:
People often try to save time when entering data by abbreviating terms. If these abbreviations are not consistent, it can cause errors in the dataset.

Differences in capitalisation, spacing and genders of adjectives can all cause errors.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body: A duplicate record is where the same piece of data has been entered more than once. Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was already an entry.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body:
Redundant data is anything that is not relevant to your work with the dataset. Often a dataset has been created for a specific purpose which requires details you may not need.

Common occurrences of redundant data include rows that represent total amounts.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Mixed numerical scales
_items.body: Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. In budget datasets, for example, the units are often in the millions. 1,200,000 often becomes 1.2m. However, smaller amounts like 800,000 are still written in full. For a machine, this means they read the larger figure as 1.2, which causes errors.

_items.title: Mixed ranges
_items.body: Data is sometimes measured in ranges, such as age or salary range. In order for a machine to understand these ranges it is important to separate the high and low values.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Spelling errors are often difficult to identify in tabular data.

Don’t forget to run your data through a spell-checker to catch spelling errors.

title: Exercise: Cleaning data
body:
For this exercise you will need a copy of Open Refine. During courses, a number of online instances of Open Refine are available from the course menu.

Each part of the exercise also requires one of three datasets

  • Dataset 1: Louisiana Secretary of State Officials
  • Dataset 2: Projects Dataset
  • Dataset 3: UK GP Earnings

To get started, download the data cleaning exercise from the link below.

Get started with data cleaning open data

title: Enriching open data
body:
Enriching data is eqivalent to combining data. To enrich a dataset, you take one dataset and add relevant data to it from another with the intention of discovering something new.

Examples including taking a list of company numbers and adding information about their last financial return. Or taking a list of postal codes of places and adding data on which region each place is within. When plotting data on a map, enriching place data with a coordinate system is critical to plot the data and a common use of enriching services.

When enriching data you need to be careful that both datasets are available under licences that permit you to combine them with other data. A no-derivitives licence is not appropriate in this scenario.

title: Exercise: Pivot and enrich data
body: To prepare data for visulising may require the reduction (pivot) and/or enriching of the source data. The two exercises here take you through how to reduce and enrich a number of datasets.

_items.title: Creating a pivot table
_items.body:
Being able to create a pivot table is a key operation of any modern spreadsheet pacakge. Pick from the examples and exercises below to get started with create a pivot table from source data.

FCO Spend Data

Transactions over £25,000 from April 2010 in the UK Foreign and Comonwealth Office (FCO).

Download | View source

Create a pivot table

Tanzania education data

Perforance of schools with 40 or more pupils accross Tanzania

Download | View source

Create a pivot table

_items.title: Enriching open data
_items.body:
Enriching open data can be challenging, fortunately Refine is able to do a lot more than just data cleaning. Refine is also a powerful tool for combining and enriching datasets using online services and API endpoints.

The following dataset has been prepared for clearning

  • UK FCO Transactions April 2010 pivot table

      • Download the exercise below to find out how to enrich this dataset on company spending with data from Open Corporates.

      Enrich data in refine

title: Goals: Communication vs Understanding
body: With the data preparation complete, visualising is usually the next stage on the agenda of any project. Before you begin the process however it is worth planning what story you want to tell using the data and how a visualisation can help tell this story. Let's first have a look at the goals of visualising data.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to discover more.

_items.title: Communication
_items.body:
Powerful messages need a simple way to communicate them. Bar charts, pie charts and big clear numbers are a very effective way to communicate.

Other effective methods use large visuals and introduce figures that may help people relate to the story (e.g. stick figures could be added to represent the number of people with the visual here).

_graphic.alt: Terroism deaths versus gun-related deaths in the U.S.
_graphic.title: Terroism deaths versus gun-related deaths in the U.S.

_items.title: Understanding
_items.body:
Sometimes there can be multiple stories or points of interest. This often leads to a more complex visualisation where a greater level of engagement is required to reach understanding.

Commonly such visualisations will present multiple dimensions of data. This makes a clear message hard to spot. Additionally, this means that there is a chance that each viewer could come to a different conclusion depending on their own background and connection to the story.

As a tip, never try and present one clear message with a multi-dimensional and complex visualisation.

title: Speeding up communication
body: Our brain likes information presented visualisually. Likewise when visualising data it is worth appealing to the brains visual processes.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how.

_items.title: Cognitive processes
_items.body:
The key to good visualisation is to apply some cognitive theory relating to how our brains take in information.

The light from our eyes is passed to our occipital lobe, here there are two parallel routes that process the information; the dorsal stream and the ventral stream.

While the ventral stream is very slow, the dorsal stream is very quick to react to where things are and what is happening. If someone throws something at you unexpectedly, it's the dorsal stream that will react to either help defend you; you act without thinking.

The dorsal stream can also be used to help messages 'pop out' from a visualisation

_items.title: Using pop out
_items.body:
Pop out helps direct the eye to the correct place. The Dorsal stream reacts quickly to patterns and/or significant differences presented visually.

Pop out works best when a combination of different visual cues are used in combination, e.g. colour, size and line thickness.

In the case here a combination or colour and thinkness guide the eye towards the steepest line. This line represents the first high speed train from Paris to Lyon. The steepness of the line is the speed!

_items.title: Using colour
_items.body:
Colour is most effectively used in categories and on scales that have clear meaning. Here red, amber and green represent risk from most dangerous to safest, just like in traffic lights.

Scientists like using continuous colour scales, however most only know about the rainbow and here the colours have no meaning, they are simply in an order. Using continuous colour scales is not advised for representing data.

When using colour, either use a well known categorical scale, or use one colour and vary the hue, saturation or brightness to represent different levels. If wanting to reveal detail, use a greyscale as our eyes are much more sensitive to black and white then colour.

_graphic.alt: How to survive a plane crash
_graphic.title: How to survive a plane crash

title: 'Big' Numbers
body:
Rather than a graph, presenting a story simply using numbers can be very effective. Big numbers like $60bn are unimaginably big for most people and create high impact. Small numbers can use presented in a large print in order to appear 'big'.

Other tricks with numbers involve comparators (shown here), translating numbers to percentages, or looking at multipliers. For example if the chance of something happening (e.g. winning the lottery) has gone from 1 in 1,000,000 people to 2 in 1,000,000 people, then it has doubled!

title: Simple charts give powerful messages
body:
If all numbers are big, then simple charts can be used to convey clear messages.

Enhancing bar charts and pie charts with graphics and well placed text can also aid the clear understanding.

This said, seeing that the graph on the left is comparing the revenue of one produce to the total revenue of an entire other company, can still be difficult to see.

title: Maps: Where things happen is important
displayTitle: Maps: Where things happen is important
body:
Many data stories have a location aspect to them, thus using a map should seem logical. However, maps are complex and can add completely unnecessary detail and dimensions that could confuse the reader.

The example shown here details all the empty and unused building in Detroit. Having the map showing all buildings is essential.

Aaron Koblin's flight patterns is a good example of a spacial visualisation that doesn't require an underlying map layer.

title: Interactive visualisations
body:
Adding interaction allows for self exploration and higher levels of engagement.

Many visualizations can tips aspects are click upon. More advanced interaction allows for the filtering and digging into the data being displayed.

When creating interactive visualisation, each point of interactivity should be both obvious to find and obvious in what it does.

title: Point and click tools
body: In addition to excel there are a number of free (or cheap) tools that can help you visulise data quickly. These point and click tools don't require any technical coding knowledge but as a result do limit the types of outputs that are possible.

_items.title: Heatmaps with numbers (plot.ly)
_items.body:
Plot.ly provides a simple point and click service to help you produce interactive online visulisations. Think of it a little like excel charts on the web. It is a young service, but certainly one to watch.

You will need the following dataset for this exercise:

  • Plot.ly exercise dataset

    • Get hands-on with plot.ly

_items.title: Google charts
_items.body: If you load up a blank Google Sheet (avilable via Google Docs) and then click Insert->Chart there are a whole host of free charting tools. The more advanced ones come with sample datasets for what kind of data structure is required for each.

_items.title: Interactive dasahboards with DataSeed
_items.body:
Dataseed is a new tool that instantly creates interactive crossfilters of datasets.

Why not try dataset out with the following datasets:

FCO Spend Data

Transactions over £25,000 from April 2010 in the UK Foreign and Comonwealth Office (FCO).

Download | View source

Tanzania education data

Perforance of schools with 40 or more pupils accross Tanzania

Download | View source

title: Maps and GIS with CartoDB
body:
CartoDB is a very popular online tool for creating geographic visualisations on maps. It has simple wizards to help you get started, but also allows you to expose the code and customise your GIS queries to take complete control. CartoDB can also merge and boundry locate geographic data without you having to write complex GIS queries yourself.

Several exercises have been developed to help you explore the features of CartoDB.

_items.title: Election maps in Singapore
_items.body:
This exercise takes you through how to create a colour coded election winners map from a number of source datasets. The datasets will be combined in CartoDB and then a wizard is used to create the map.

There is an extension exercise that also uses cartoDBs geographic merge fearure to locate places within districticts.

You will need the following datasets for this exercise:

  • Singapore electorial districts boundary file (2011)
  • Singapore election winners (2011)
  • Singapore friendly buildings data

Get hands-on with CartoDB

_items.title: Population and education in Tanzania
_items.body:
This exercise focusses on plotting populatrion stastics for the different districts in Tanzania. This is then combined this with educational attainment of each district.

You will need the following datasets for this exercise:

Tanzania district boundaries

Offical boundary files for Tanzaniafrom the National Bureau for Statistics

Download | View source

Tanzania population data

Official statistics on Tanzania from the National Bureau for Statistics

Download | View source

Tanzania education data

Perforance of schools with 40 or more pupils accross Tanzania

Download | View source

Get hands-on with CartoDB

title: Treemaps in D3js
body:
D3js is the most popular low level open source visulisation library currently available. Many of the other services, such as Dataseed, Plot.ly and CartoDB build on top of the D3js library. However to unlock the full potential of D3, why not try to write some D3 javascript code yourself?

This exercise takes you though how to create an interactive online treemap from an existing example.

There is only one exercise however you can choose which dataset you want to explore.

_items.title: UK Government flight data
_items.body:
Explore where UK Government officials have traveled to, in what class, and how much it cost with this interactive treemap.

The data is preloaded into the example.

Follow both links below to get started with this exercise.

Treemaps exercise sheet

Treemaps D3js code environement

_items.title: Tanzania school performance
_items.body:
Find out where the best and worst performing schools are in Tanzania by region.

The data is preloaded into the example.

Follow both links below to get started with this exercise.

Treemaps exercise sheet

Treemaps D3js code environement

title: Open data in practice: Visulisation and communication
displayTitle: Open data in practice: Visulisation and communication
body:
Communicating impact from data is a key skill of any modern data worker. This course has explored how it is not as simple as just taking any dataset and pressing the graph button. Once a dataset is cleaned and enriched, it might be possible to discover insight, then it is necessary to think carefully about how to communicate this insight.

From trying to visualise too much data, to choice of colour, there are many crucial decisions that need careful thought and time to implement when visulising data. Take a look over this course page and see if you can spot all the little aspects that make the page as appealing as it can be.

There are two other sessions in this course that focus on publising and innovating with open data.

Practical publication
Open data innovation
